abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the Environmental
            Institutions Development Project is seen as highly
            successful with highly likely sustainability and a
            substantial institutional development impact. Both bank and
            borrower performance is considered satisfactory. The
            development of new or less costly technology had a positive
            impact on project implementation, while frequent turnover of
            government control disrupted continuity. Lessons learned
            include: a) projects that promote a cultural shift within
            government succeed better if the overall environment of
            societal change support them; b) complexity of the project
            has to be commensurate with the capacity of the borrower; c)
            adequate supervision is important; d) World Bank and Project
            Implementation Units (PIUs) are not neutral, but rather can
            impact internal institutional dynamics; e) continuity of key
            personnel is important and helps; f) World Bank's
            current focus on outcomes as opposed to outputs is an
            improvement over the previous style of project design; g)
            environmental management is a highly political topic that
            poses project risks; h) risk-taking in institutional
            development can pay off; i) institutional sustainability can
            be through of differently; j) environmental education is
            low-cost and high-return and k) adequately aligning sectoral
            and environmental objectives, particularly in the sectoral
            ministries, is crucial for success.
